questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with shortness of breath. He is a known case of COPD and has had similar episodes in the past, which required hospitalization. The classification according to GOLD’s criteria was moderate COPD. What are the likely PFT values of the patient considering this classification?
questions.correct_answer: A. FEV1 / FVC < 0.7 and FEV1 50% to 80%

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with persistent hypertension and muscle weakness. Laboratory tests reveal low serum potassium levels and metabolic alkalosis. Given these findings, which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for his symptoms?

A 40-year-old patient presents with symptoms of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), including chronic cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath. The patient has a history of liver cirrhosis. Upon further evaluation, it is discovered that the patient has impaired neutralization of elastase from macrophages, leading to bronchiectasis. What is the underlying deficiency or dysfunction in this patient's condition?

A 68-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents to the emergency department with increased shortness of breath, productive cough with yellow sputum, and wheezing for the past 3 days. He has a known diagnosis of severe COPD (FEV1 35% predicted) and is on tiotropium, salbutamol as needed, and fluticasone-salmeterol. On examination, he is tachypneic (RR 28), using accessory muscles, and has diffuse wheezes bilaterally. SpO₂ is 87% on room air, improving to 92% with 2 L/min nasal oxygen. Chest X-ray shows no consolidation. Arterial blood gas reveals pH 7.32, PaCO₂ 55 mmHg, HCO₃⁻ 28 mmol/L. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start empirical antibiotics and increase inhaled corticosteroid dose

options.label: D
options.text: Increase oxygen to 6 L/min via face mask

questions.text: In a patient presenting with respiratory distress and cardiogenic shock, which type of respiratory failure is primarily caused by underperfusion of respiratory muscles?

A patient presents with breathlessness on exertion and a dry cough for a month. On chest examination, there are fine inspiratory crackles. HRCT shows a bilateral, subpleural, and basilar honeycombing pattern. Which pattern is expected in the pulmonary function tests of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: FEV1/FVC ratio increased, and DLCO increased

options.label: B
options.text: FEV1/FVC ratio increased, and DLCO decreased

options.label: C
options.text: FEV1/FVC ratio decreased, and DLCO decreased

options.label: D
options.text: FEV1/FVC ratio decreased, and DLCO increased

questions.correct_answer: B. FEV1/FVC ratio increased, and DLCO decreased

questions.text: A young male had an episode of sudden breathing difficulty and collapsed when he visited a hill station. He is a known case of bronchial asthma. He was rushed to the ER, and the doctor diagnosed it as severe acute asthma. Arterial blood gas investigation reveals: pH = 7.24 PaCO2 = 60 mmHg PaO2 = 65 mmHg HCO3 = 24 mEq/L What is the diagnosis?

A 40-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of persistent hypertension and occasional muscle weakness. Laboratory tests reveal hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. Further evaluation indicates low renin levels. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for the management of this patient's condition?

A 40-year-old patient who underwent kidney transplantation presents with new-onset skin lesions. On further evaluation, it is determined that the patient has post-transplantation lymphoma. Which of the following infections is most commonly associated with post-transplantation lymphoma?

A 60-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents with fatigue and muscle weakness. Medications include insulin, losartan, and spironolactone. On examination, blood pressure is 138/86 mmHg, pulse 78/min. There is no edema. Laboratory results show: • Na⁺: 136 mEq/L • K⁺: 6.2 mEq/L • Cl⁻: 110 mEq/L • HCO₃⁻: 18 mEq/L • BUN: 28 mg/dL • Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL • Arterial pH: 7.32 • Urine pH: 5.0 • Anion gap: Normal Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl with a known diagnosis of minimal change nephrotic syndrome has experienced multiple relapses over the past year. Each episode responded to oral prednisolone, but she relapses within 10 days of stopping steroids. She has now had three relapses in the last six months. On examination, she has mild periorbital puffiness but is otherwise active and afebrile. Her urine dipstick is 3+ for protein, and serum albumin is 2.2 g/dL. Which of the following best defines her current clinical status?

A 55-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to his primary care physician for a routine check-up. During the examination, the physician orders a spot urine sample to screen for diabetic nephropathy. Which of the following laboratory tests would be most appropriate for assessing renal function in this patient?

A 62-year-old diabetic man underwent an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair 2 days ago. He is being treated with gentamicin for a urinary tract infection. His urine output has fallen to 300 mL over 24 hours, and his serum creatinine has risen from 1.1 mg/dL on admission to 1.9 mg/dL. Which of the following laboratory values would be most consistent with a prerenal etiology of his renal insufficiency?

options.label: C
options.text: Central venous pressure reading of 10 mm Hg

questions.correct_answer: B. Urinary sodium level of 10 mEq/L

questions.text: An 18-year-old marathon runner has been training during the summer. He is brought to the emergency room disoriented after collapsing on the track. His temperature is 102°F. A Foley catheter is placed and reveals reddish urine with 3+ blood on dipstick and no cells seen microscopically. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his urine?

A 22-year-old man complains of acute hemoptysis over the past week. He denies smoking or pulmonary disease. His blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and his physical examination is normal. His urinalysis also shows microscopic hematuria and red blood cell casts. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Metastatic renal cell carcinoma to the lungs

options.label: B
options.text: Acute tuberculosis of the kidneys and lungs

questions.text: A 72-year-old man develops severe pain and swelling in both knees, shortly after undergoing an abdominal hernia repair surgery. Physical examination shows warmth and swelling of both knees with large effusions. Arthrocentesis of the right knee reveals the presence of intracellular and extracellular weakly positive birefringent crystals in the synovial fluid. Gram stain is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old woman was seen by her physician due to pain in her hands, wrists, and knees. She is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. Which of the following treatments will reduce joint inflammation and slow progression of the disease?

Which of the following will be the earliest involvement in a 30-year-old male presenting with complaints of chronic lower back pain and stiffness, particularly in the morning and after periods of inactivity, along with buttock pain and difficulty bending forward to touch his toes?

A 12-year-old boy presents with fever, joint pain, and difficulty walking. His symptoms started with pain in his knees, which then improved and migrated to the ankles. On examination, he has a temperature of 38.5°C, a soft systolic murmur at the apex, and tender swollen ankles. ESR and CRP are elevated. Antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer is high. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman presents with fatigue, low-grade fever, joint pain, and swelling of fingers for 3 months. She also reports hair thinning, oral ulcers, and episodes of dark-colored urine. She has a malar rash and notes worsening of symptoms after sun exposure. Examination reveals synovitis in small joints and bilateral ankle edema. Investigations: • Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL • WBC: 2,800/mm³ • Platelets: 100,000/mm³ • Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL • Urinalysis: 3+ protein, RBC casts • ANA: Positive (1:1280, homogeneous pattern) • Anti-dsDNA: Strongly positive • C3, C4: Low What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Start low-dose corticosteroids and monitor renal function

options.label: C
options.text: Start high-dose corticosteroids and consider renal biopsy

questions.correct_answer: C. Start high-dose corticosteroids and consider renal biopsy
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why the other options are incorrect: • A. Hydroxychloroquine and NSAIDs – Good for mild cutaneous and joint symptoms, but not sufficient for nephritis. • B. Low-dose corticosteroids and monitor – Delayed treatment can lead to irreversible renal damage. • D. Azathioprine – Used for maintenance, not for initial treatment of active renal disease.
